en: To the Rhine with the 79th Infantry Division, 25 Oct to 14 Feb. 1945
Route map with cartoons, part of a series
To the Rhine with the 79th Infantry Division, 25 Oct to 14 Feb. 1945 -- Pont-Ã -Mousson (France)
To the Rhine with the 79th Infantry Division, 25 Oct to 14 Feb. 1945 -- Metz (France)
To the Rhine with the 79th Infantry Division, 25 Oct to 14 Feb. 1945 -- Nomeny (France)
Canvas for To the Rhine with the 79th Infantry Division, 25 Oct to 14 Feb. 1945

body.value:
Cartoon of American soldiers watching a performance.  Female singer, clown juggling, piano player.  Sign "USO Camp Shows."

Caption: "Only eight days in this rest period - days filled with training of reinforcements, more repair and maintenance, a few movies, clean clothes, then once more - destination, Belgium"
"After sixteen days in a rest area southwest of Luneville spent in maintenance, repair, and training the division was alerted for the race to the Rhine"
"More than two months after harrying the fleeing Germans through Saverne Gap the Division moved westward again on February 4 headed for Pont-a-Mousson and rest"
Cartoon of destroyed German column.  Fighting vehicles including tanks, artillery, horse carts, and a crashed plane.  Dead mule in foreground
American troops entrenched on a hillside in winter.  Machine gun position and mounted artillery.  December 1944 in Eastern France.

Cartoon of a small building with a blue sign front. "You Are Now Entering Germany Through the Courtesy of the 79th Infantry Division." Sign has the division's Cross of Lorraine.  Small object, maybe a can, below the sign.

Black and white cartoon of fighting during Operation Northwind.  Not colored like cartoons in this series.  Possibly a different artist.  American soldiers advancing through a village with shellfire.  Several bodies in the streets.  Street sign pointing toward Hatten. "House by house and stone by stone, lacking blood plasma and ammunition, the 315 Inf made of Hatten and Rittershoffen a burial ground for many of Hitler's best troops."
Unit crest of the 79th Infantry (the Cross of Lorraine). Hand written "map no. 3"
